It has never been the purpose or
tne desire of the NEWS-LETTER to create a panic, to "view with alarm,"
or, in general, to attempt to exaggerate the importance of an issue by an
emotional harangue. We have always
tried to consider a problem as calmly
and as dispassionately as possible—
an as impersonally.
But when an issue as vital as that
presented by the election of 1936
arises, we feel justified in taking a
vigorous stand and in expressing an
unequivocal opinion.

Editorial
(Continued from Page 1, Col. 4)
successful phases of the New Deal.
Until Mr. Roosevelt's inauguration,
the tariff was used as a cow to be
milked into private pails. The Republican party today proposes to return
to its traditional isolation and aloofness. They would back-face on the
reciprocal trade agreements which
have proven a boon to the American
farmer and to American industry.
These agreements and the power to
make them the Republicans would
abrogate—and they would insist upon
the payment of foreign debts while
depriving the nations of the means
of paying them.
The NEWS-LETTER would take issue
with President Roosevelt on his sabotage of the World Economic Conference
of 1933. But his foreign policy since
then has been not only sane but conducive to peace. In his Chataqua adadre-ss, Mr. Roosevelt made many correct statements about the need of
peace. He has fortified American neutrality. He has refused to let the flag
follow the dollar. He has antagonized
the interests which draw profits from
war— and has consequently strengthened the hope of peace for America.
* * * *
Mr. Roosevelt's experiment in democratic government has been of the

real essence of democracy. Every factor in democracy has been diligently
protected and applied. He has tried
to create an economy based upon the
peculiarities of the American situation
a system which would promote happiness of the masses of the
American people by the sage exploitation, rather than the waste, of the
natural resources of the potentially
richest nation in the world.
Mr. Roosevelt calls it an "economic
constitutional order." What's in a
name? It is, essentially, a balanced
democratic social state in which social
control is used intelligently to maintain the balance of society. He has
realized the fact that free competition
and individual initiative, when given
full reign, prove their own executors.
The period of hasty experimentation
is over. There is little doubt that Mr.
Roosevelt has pulled America out of
a dangerous rut — both psychologically and actually. His case is strong
statistically. The job for the next four
years is on of consolidation of
ground gained in the sense of scratching deeper the surface of social security and in securing the benefits of recent experimentation.
We believe the record asks that Mr.
Roosevelt be re-elected. But more important, more fundamental than this
is the fact that Mr. Roosevelt has
acccmplished everything within a democratic form of government. He has
proven that democracy is capable of
facing a crisis. He has renewed confidence in libertanian government.

Lettertothe Editor
Brick-bats, brick-bats, brick-bats! A
student takes exception with the
NEWS-LETTER and makes a silly
statement — the one in the last
paragraph but one.
To the Editor of the NEWS LEI
Sir:
I too dislike Mr. Hearst, as a man
and as a journalist. In your declaration of political sentiment you assert
that you hate him; in fat you waste
much paper in repeating yourself on
that point. I take it you object only
to his character, because you certainly
could not object to his journalistic
methods and then proceed to use
them.
Mr. Hearst's deliberate lies, misinterpretation of facts, and playing up
false issues all have close parallels in
your editorial of Oct. 6. The very fact
that it appeared on the front page
stinks of Hearst methods. Only the
decorum of your newspaper prevents
me from using stronger language.
In the first two paragraphs you appeal to the Muse of public virtue according to accepted Hearst technique.
In the third you attack Landon personally and introduce the false issue
of Fascism, exactly as Hearst introduced Communism. In the fifth paragraph, the sixth, the seventh, the
eighth ,the ninth, the tenth, the eleventh, the twelfth, the thirteenth, the
fourteenth, the fifteenth, the sixteenth, the seventeenth, the eighteenth, and the nineteenth paragraphs
you repeat and reiterate the same
false and ridiculous charge over and
over. Why did you bother to rewrite
it each time; you could have achieved
the same effect by merely repeating
it verbatim again and again. If this
is not Hearstism, what is?
You also demonstrate a striking
ignorance of facts. You assail Mr.
Landon's "record of consistency" and
"as an administrator". I take it the
last refers to the closing of several
Kansas schools. Misrepresentation,

pure and simple. Those schools were
closed so that their pupils could attend
better and more efficient consolidated
schools.
The charge of inconsistency, I suppose, is based on his use of Federal
aid in Kansas and later opposing the
New Deal policies. If this were a
change of heart (and I think it is
not), would it be as damning as Mr.
Roosevelt's deliberate promises to reduce governmental expenditures and
his equally deliberate violation of
these promises?
I say that Mr. Landon has not
changed his mind because he still
supports security legislation. What he
Is really opposed to is the blind experimentation with the Nation's vital
scources of supply, the inefficiency
and waste, and the dangerous centralization, of being spineless, specifically
Of being "putty, soft, formless
clay
in the hands of Mr. Hearst and of
the
Liberty League." Would you call a
man spineless who, when presented
With a platform composed by the
powers that be in the Republican
party, whoever they may be, refuses
to accept it unless certain specific interpretations are placed on vague
Parts of it; for example, that a "sound
currency" be interpreted as one which
is based on gold? Would you?
You rant and rave about personal,
civil, and economic liberty. Did it
ever occur to you that the loss of
these to many Europeans came
through the centralization of power
in the executive office?
You speak of a "Landon-HearstLiberty League-Coughlin-TownsendSmith alliance". You would not, by
any chance, be insulting the integrity
of a Catholic priest, would you?
To finish this off, I would like to
remind you that Hearst, Du Pont and
Many of the Liberty Leaguers were
"great guys" when they were supporting F D. R. in 1932.
Try again, Mr. Editor.
J. E. Thomas, Jr.

Editorial
(Continued from Page 1, Col. 4)
successful phases of the New Deal.
Until Mr. Roosevelt's inauguration,
the tariff was used as a cow to be
milked into private pails. The Republican party today proposes to return
to its traditional isolation and aloofness. They would back-face on the
reciprocal trade agreements which
have proven a boon to the American
farmer and to American industry.
These agreements and the power to
make them the Republicans would
abrogate—and they would insist upon
the payment of foreign debts while
depriving the nations of the means
of paying them.
The NEWS-LETTER would take issue
with President Roosevelt on his sabotage of the World Economic Conference
of 1933. But his foreign policy since
then has been not only sane but conducive to peace. In his Chataqua adadre-ss, Mr. Roosevelt made many correct statements about the need of
peace. He has fortified American neutrality. He has refused to let the flag
follow the dollar. He has antagonized
the interests which draw profits from
war— and has consequently strengthened the hope of peace for America.
* * * *
Mr. Roosevelt's experiment in democratic government has been of the

real essence of democracy. Every factor in democracy has been diligently
protected and applied. He has tried
to create an economy based upon the
peculiarities of the American situation
a system which would promote happiness of the masses of the
American people by the sage exploitation, rather than the waste, of the
natural resources of the potentially
richest nation in the world.
Mr. Roosevelt calls it an "economic
constitutional order." What's in a
name? It is, essentially, a balanced
democratic social state in which social
control is used intelligently to maintain the balance of society. He has
realized the fact that free competition
and individual initiative, when given
full reign, prove their own executors.
The period of hasty experimentation
is over. There is little doubt that Mr.
Roosevelt has pulled America out of
a dangerous rut — both psychologically and actually. His case is strong
statistically. The job for the next four
years is on of consolidation of
ground gained in the sense of scratching deeper the surface of social security and in securing the benefits of recent experimentation.
We believe the record asks that Mr.
Roosevelt be re-elected. But more important, more fundamental than this
is the fact that Mr. Roosevelt has
acccmplished everything within a democratic form of government. He has
proven that democracy is capable of
facing a crisis. He has renewed confidence in libertanian government.

Lettertothe Editor
Brick-bats, brick-bats, brick-bats! A
student takes exception with the
NEWS-LETTER and makes a silly
statement — the one in the last
paragraph but one.
To the Editor of the NEWS LEI
Sir:
I too dislike Mr. Hearst, as a man
and as a journalist. In your declaration of political sentiment you assert
that you hate him; in fat you waste
much paper in repeating yourself on
that point. I take it you object only
to his character, because you certainly
could not object to his journalistic
methods and then proceed to use
them.
Mr. Hearst's deliberate lies, misinterpretation of facts, and playing up
false issues all have close parallels in
your editorial of Oct. 6. The very fact
that it appeared on the front page
stinks of Hearst methods. Only the
decorum of your newspaper prevents
me from using stronger language.
In the first two paragraphs you appeal to the Muse of public virtue according to accepted Hearst technique.
In the third you attack Landon personally and introduce the false issue
of Fascism, exactly as Hearst introduced Communism. In the fifth paragraph, the sixth, the seventh, the
eighth ,the ninth, the tenth, the eleventh, the twelfth, the thirteenth, the
fourteenth, the fifteenth, the sixteenth, the seventeenth, the eighteenth, and the nineteenth paragraphs
you repeat and reiterate the same
false and ridiculous charge over and
over. Why did you bother to rewrite
it each time; you could have achieved
the same effect by merely repeating
it verbatim again and again. If this
is not Hearstism, what is?
You also demonstrate a striking
ignorance of facts. You assail Mr.
Landon's "record of consistency" and
"as an administrator". I take it the
last refers to the closing of several
Kansas schools. Misrepresentation,

pure and simple. Those schools were

The charge of inconsistency, I suppose, is based on his use of Federal
aid in Kansas and later opposing the
New Deal policies. If this were a
change of heart (and I think it is
not), would it be as damning as Mr.
Roosevelt's deliberate promises to reduce governmental expenditures and
his equally deliberate violation of
these promises?
I say that Mr. Landon has not
changed his mind because he still
supports security legislation. What he
Is really opposed to is the blind experimentation with the Nation's vital
scources of supply, the inefficiency
and waste, and the dangerous centralization, of being spineless, specifically
Of being "putty, soft, formless
clay
in the hands of Mr. Hearst and of
the
Liberty League." Would you call a
man spineless who, when presented
With a platform composed by the
powers that be in the Republican
party, whoever they may be, refuses
to accept it unless certain specific interpretations are placed on vague
Parts of it; for example, that a "sound
currency" be interpreted as one which
is based on gold? Would you?
You rant and rave about personal,
civil, and economic liberty. Did it
ever occur to you that the loss of
these to many Europeans came
through the centralization of power
in the executive office?
You speak of a "Landon-HearstLiberty League-Coughlin-TownsendSmith alliance". You would not, by
any chance, be insulting the integrity
of a Catholic priest, would you?
To finish this off, I would like to
remind you that Hearst, Du Pont and
Many of the Liberty Leaguers were
"great guys" when they were supporting F D. R. in 1932.
Try again, Mr. Editor.
J. E. Thomas, Jr.
